answers.answer: Dear Peg:The motor and sensory neuropathies are a large group of diseases that can be from a number of etiologies.  Is there this type of neuropathy in your family?  Have you been on chemotherapy?  Do you have a generalized disorder such as diabetes?  Do you drink alcohol to  the extent of being a daily drinker for many years?  Do you have epilepsy and take medication?  So, the list is large and alot depends on your family history and overall health.The motor and sensory neuropathies means that you have a disease of the medium to large myelinated nerves in your limbs.  These disorders affect both nerves that transmit power to muscles and also sensation back to the brain.The etiology of the nerve disorder predicts the progression.  Without knowing this I can't tell you the progression.As a guess, being in the hands and feet suggest a systemic disorder.Sincerely,CCF Neuro MD
As I have read this site, I keep seeing references too systemic disorders.  What are systemic disorders?

question: I have just been diagnosed with sensormotor polyneuropathy.  My doctor is very limited in explaining.  We have yet to find the cause; though we are looking.  My question is what does the above subject mean? and what do you do to stop the progression and what happens next to my body.  It is mostly in my feet and hands right now.  Thank you so very much for your time and possible response.
title: Severe atrophy of the mylinated axon
